Package com.ericdaugherty.lib.bean

Provide dynamic implementations of JavaBean Interfaces.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
BeanFactory Provides a factory for dynamic JavaBean implementations.
BeanHandler Provides a Dynamic Proxy implementation for JavaBean interfaces.
BeanService Provides common methods helpful when dealing with JavaBean interfaces.
 

Package com.ericdaugherty.lib.bean Description

Provide dynamic implementations of JavaBean Interfaces.

Traditionally, JavaBean implementers have had to define an implementation for each JavaBean in their systems.  However, many of these JavaBeans may simply be "value" or "info" object. (A simple object that is only used to pass information.  For more information, please refer to Sun's Pattern Definition).  Instead of providing implementations for each individual JavaBean, these beans can instead be defined as interfaces, and their implementations can be dynamically provided using this package. 

By defining JavaBeans as interfaces, an application's business tier can choose to return differing implementations of the JavaBean depending upon what type of request was made, and who initiated the request.

Usage

BeanFactory provides methods to create dynamic implementations of JavaBean interfaces.  These methods (createBean( Class beanInterfaceClass ) and createBean( Class[] beanInterfaceClasses ) ) accept either a single interface, or an array of interfaces to implement.  The Object returned by these methods can be cast to the interface(s) passed as parameters.  However, although this method will return an implementation to any interface, only JavaBean methods will be implemented (isXXX(), getXXX(), and setXXX(param)).

BeanHandler provides the actual implementation.  Because this class is not thread-safe, this implementation should only be used when the implementation will only be accessed by a single thread.

BeanService provides methods to manipulate JavaBeans.  Currently, the only method defined provides a the ability to copy one JavaBean to another, assuming they either implement the same interface, or extend from the same class (or actually ARE the same class).
